page.title: 19Local History Priors Marston
page.content: MARSTON means "settlement near a marsh" from the Anglo Saxon "merise" (marsh) and "ton" (settlement). PRIORS was added by Coventry Priory (given the parish by Earl Leofric in 1043), to endorse their claim to ownership & avoid confusion with other Marstons. At the time of the Domesday Survey in 1086 a settlement is recorded. The village is on the Old Salt Road (recorded by charter in 998) between Droitwich & the Midland markets, salt being used to preserve meat & hides. The ancient Ridgeway, linking a chain of British Camps that once stretched across the land, runs along the ridge between the Thames & Severn catchments. Drovers used the Welsh Road for centuries to drive cattle & sheep from Wales to the London markets.
